desc: TRAF7 encodes an E3 ubiquitin ligase that targets several proteins in the NF-kB pathway and interacts with multiple signaling pathways. TRAF7 is frequently mutated in meningiomas and is downregulated in breast tumors.

TRAF7 encodes an E3 ubiquitin ligase that influences signal transduction in several ways. TRAF7 appears to be an inhibitor of NF-kB activation and an agonist for the JNK-AP1 pathway (PMID:15001576,14743216). TRAF7 targets ubiquitination of c-FLIP, an antiapoptotic molecule, as well as p53 and TRAF7 downregulation is found in breast tumors, correlating with the high levels of p53 (PMID:14743216, 23128672). The TRAF7 gene was found as recurrently altered in meningiomas. TRAF7 mutations, which were always exclusive of NF2 mutations (frequently mutated in meningiomas, 36%) were observed in nearly one-fourth of the meningiomas examined (n = 72). It is notable that 67 of the 72 TRAF7 mutations, including 15 recurrent mutations, all map to the WD40 domains (PMID:23348505). TRAF7 mutations are present in 93% of secretory meningiomas (29/30) and are also confined to the seven WD40 domains in the C-terminal portion spanning exons 13 to 20. In most cases, the TRAF7 alterations resulted in single amino acid substitutions, but two tumors were found to harbor splice site mutations (PMID:23404370). in addition, meningiomas with TRAF7 mutations are almost always characterized by the mutation K409Q in the gene for the transcription factor Kruppel-like factor 4 (KLF4). The combined TRAF7/KLF4 mutation characterizes secretory meningiomas and provides a molecular marker for this grade 1 subtype (PMID:23404370, 25993161). Moreover, exome sequencing of 49 MCCs (merkel cell carcinoma) showed TRAF7 to be mutated in MCPyV (cell polyomavirus) - negative MCCs (PMID:26655088). Finally, the methylation frequency of the TRAF7 gene was remarkably modified by genistein treatment, a soy phytoestrogen, making it a potential target for developing therapeutic agents for prostate cancer, where DNA methylation is significantly associated with tumor initiation, progression, and metastasis (PMID:25831061).
